perturbation.original_text: WHEREAS, Licensor is the registrant of certain domain names as more particularly described below that are related to the Business which it desires to license to Licensee and Licensee desires to obtain a license from Licensor to such domain names to use in connection with its operation of the Business on the terms and conditions set forth herein; and
perturbation.changed_text: WHEREAS, Licensor is the registrant of certain domain names as more particularly described below that are related to the Venture which it desires to license to Licensee and Licensee desires to obtain a license from Licensor to such domain names to use in connection with its operation of the Business on the terms and conditions set forth herein; and
perturbation.explanation: The term 'Business' is specifically defined in Article I, while 'Venture' is not. This creates ambiguity as to whether the domain names are licensed for the defined 'Business' or an undefined 'Venture'.

perturbation.original_text: 3.1. Licensee Control. Subject to the terms and conditions of this Agreement, Licensee shall be entitled to exercise exclusive control over all aspects of the websites and the Business associated with the Licensed Domain Names including, without limitation, the operation, the look-and-feel and the Content of such websites.
perturbation.changed_text: 3.1. Licensee Control. Subject to the terms and conditions of this Agreement, Licensee shall be entitled to exercise considerable influence over all aspects of the websites and the Business associated with the Licensed Domain Names including, without limitation, the operation, the look-and-feel and the Content of such websites.
perturbation.explanation: Changing 'exclusive control' to 'considerable influence' weakens the Licensee's rights and creates ambiguity, because the original wording entails the licensee has ultimate authority on the website, while the new wording implies the licensor may also exert control.

perturbation.original_text: 10.15. Force Majeure. Neither Party shall be liable for failure to perform any of its obligations under this Agreement during any period in which such Party cannot perform due to hacker attack, fire, flood or other natural disaster, war, embargo, riot or the intervention of any Governmental Authority, provided, however, that the Party so delayed immediately notifies the other Party of such delay. In no event shall such nonperformance by Licensee be excused due to any such event for longer than ninety (90) days.
perturbation.changed_text: 10.15. Unforeseen Circumstances. Neither Party shall be held responsible for failure to perform any of its obligations under this Agreement during any period in which such Party cannot perform due to hacker attack, fire, flood or other natural disaster, war, embargo, riot or the intervention of any Governmental Authority, provided, however, that the Party so delayed immediately notifies the other Party of such delay. In no event shall such nonperformance by Licensee be excused due to any such event for longer than ninety (90) days.
perturbation.explanation: Changing "Force Majeure" to "Unforeseen Circumstances" broadens the scope of excused non-performance, without specifying what other events would qualify. This creates an internal contradiction by using a specific term ("Force Majeure" is usually understood to have a specific legal definition) and replacing it with a vague one, allowing for potential disputes regarding what qualifies as an "Unforeseen Circumstance" versus a traditionally understood "Force Majeure" event. This is made worse by not defining "Unforeseen Circumstances."
